text.p: Russian international long-distance telephone company Rostelekom is undervalued and ripe for growth when the economy picks up, Salomon Brothers said in a recent report which rated the shares a buy.
"In our view it is just a matter of time before the market recognises Rostelekom's long-term investment potential," it said.
Preferred shares, trading at a 30 percent discount to ordinaries and offering a guaranteed dividend, were the best buy, it added.

Salomon said Rostelekom's management was one of the best in Russia and its network was generally modern, but it said revenue growth would slow in the short term with long-distance traffic growth unlikely before 1999.

"Rostelecom's valuation reveals substantial share price upside given the potential earnings jump once the economic upturn does get under way, boosting traffic volumes in the process," the report said.
AOOT Mezhdugorodnoi i Mezhdunarodnoi Elektricheskoi Svyazi Rostelekom's 1996 net profits to international standards rose to $265 million from $247 million, it said.
